terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Alentejo countryside. Moderate elevation with rolling scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional Portuguese event. Rolling Alentejo terrain with moderate access, moderate costs, and regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: Alentejo Gravel is a regional event in Portugal‚Äîrolling Alentejo terrain with moderate elevation. The Alentejo countryside is scenic and organization is solid, but the moderate access and regional field keep it firmly in Tier 3.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A scenic Alentejo rolling gravel race. Worth it for European riders. Not practical for most international riders.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in Europe‚Äîyes, it's solid. If you're international‚Äîthere are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better value: regional gravel races. For similar Portuguese terrain: 114 Gravel Race.

logistics.food: Alentejo has full dining options. Stock nutrition.

non_negotiables.why: Alentejo rolling terrain requires sustained effort.

logistics.explanation: Mixed category starts created chaos as Rosa Kl√∂ser found herself 'in a group of 15-20 men already after 15km' ‚Äî organizational growing pains for an inaugural UCI event. The 75km drive from Faro Airport through rural Portugal requires rental car navigation to reach Ourique.

length.explanation: The winning break formed early between Malezsewski and Grosemans in a two-man escape that came down to an uphill finishing sprint. Elite men finished in 3:20:29 to 3:29:31, while Rosa Kl√∂ser dominated the women's field with a 12-minute victory gap. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: The start was 'quite hilly and technical' according to Rosa Kl√∂ser, with 'technical sections' throughout dirt roads and rural trails. Lukas Malezsewski noted 'the technical sections made it a real gravel classic' but the course doesn't require advanced rock garden skills. Less technical than The Mid South. As Lukas Malezsewski puts it: "We came here to test ourselves on one of the toughest courses in the series and to secure a ticket to Nannup. The climbs never stopped and the technical sections made it a real gravel classic."

elevation.explanation: The 120km route delivered 3,182m of climbing in a 'shark-tooth profile' where 'flat sections far and few between.' Malezsewski described how 'the climbs never stopped' creating a 'grueling grind' rather than single defining ascents. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 77¬∞F and lows of 58¬∞F, with a 40% chance of rain on any given day. November 2025 conditions allowed elite finishing times of 3:20:29 without weather complaints from the 700+ rider field. Late-season timing in southern Portugal's Mediterranean climate delivered optimal racing weather for the inaugural edition. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL.

altitude.explanation: Alentejo's rolling hills through 'golden plains, cork oak forests' sit at minimal elevation with zero altitude considerations for training or performance. The region's 'vast, open landscapes' barely register altitude concerns. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds ‚Äî no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: The route crosses Alentejo's 'vast, open landscapes' through 'golden plains, cork oak forests' on dirt roads and rural trails. Malezsewski came to 'test ourselves on one of the toughest courses in the series' through Portugal's authentic countryside.

prestige.explanation: Brand new UCI World Series event with zero history and no established reputation. Sure, it's a qualifier for Worlds, but so are dozens of other races with actual pedigree. The organizers run Granfondo Coimbra, which tells you exactly nothing about their gravel chops. As Lukas Malezsewski puts it: "We came here to test ourselves on one of the toughest courses in the series and to secure a ticket to Nannup. The climbs never stopped and the technical sections made it a real gravel classic."

race_quality.explanation: Impossible to judge race execution when they won't even publish basic details like start times, aid stations, or cutoffs. The course promises cork forests and wildflower fields, but 'full details to be communicated later' isn't confidence-inspiring. First-year events are always dice rolls.

experience.explanation: Event featured 'a dedicated area for socializing, catering, exhibitors and activities for all ages ‚Äî transforming the day into a true festival dedicated to gravel and cycling.' The 85km men's race produced an all-Portuguese podium highlighting local engagement.

community.explanation: Over 700 riders from 37 nationalities competed in the inaugural edition, creating strong international participation. The festival atmosphere with dedicated socializing areas and activities drew both elite racers hunting Worlds spots and local Portuguese riders.

field_depth.explanation: With a field of 200-400 riders, worlds qualifier status attracts riders, but it's one of many options on the calendar. October timing in rural Portugal won't pull the big guns away from established events. Expect motivated age-groupers and Europeans hunting points, not the sport's elite. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100. As Daan Grosemans puts it: "Breakaway with two, gambled on my sprint after a fast race but unfortunately one guy was faster. Nevertheless time for a well deserved off-season and let's bring the hunger for victory towards 2026."

value.explanation: Portugal delivers serious bang for your buck compared to Northern European races. Ourique isn't Lisbon pricing, and you're getting 119km through scenery with Worlds qualification potential. The 75km drive from Faro opens up Algarve accommodation options.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs ‚Ç¨50-80. Portugal keeps costs reasonable, but international travel isn't cheap. Ourique is 150km from Lisbon and 75km from Faro, meaning rental car necessity and rural lodging limitations. Entry fees are mysteriously unpublished, which never signals bargain pricing. Higher total cost than Badlands.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
